name: Arktika-M N°1
description: Same satellite bus as Elektro ([Навигатор](https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%9D%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80_(%D1%81%D0%BF%D1%83%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%BF%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%82%D1%84%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BC%D0%B0))) shot into a Molniya orbit to perform high resolution Arctic region imaging.

signals.name: RDAS
signals.description: Full resolution MSU-GS imagery. Transmitted near apogee.

signals.name: GGAK
signals.description: Seemingly unused GGAK downlink.

signals.name: DCP
signals.description: Contains DCP data, currently unsupported due to unknown modulation.

signals.name: xRIT
signals.description: Arktika satellites can broadcast xRIT just like their Elektro counterparts, but the downlink is currently unused.

name: Arktika-M N°2
description: Same satellite bus as Elektro ([Навигатор](https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%9D%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80_(%D1%81%D0%BF%D1%83%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%BF%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%82%D1%84%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BC%D0%B0))) shot into a Molniya orbit to perform high resolution Arctic region imaging.

signals.name: RDAS
signals.description: Full resolution MSU-GS imagery. Transmitted near apogee.

signals.name: GGAK
signals.description: Contains GGAK and SEM data, not supported due to the lack of documentation. Spike on the left is not a part of the signal.

signals.name: DCP
signals.description: Contains DCP data, currently unsupported due to unknown modulation.

signals.name: xRIT
signals.description: Arktika satellites can broadcast xRIT just like their Elektro counterparts, but the downlink is currently unused.

signals.name: RTD
signals.description: Encrypted everywhere except the South pole, Arctic Ocean, and over mainland US. Contains two OLS channels as well as the SSMIS sounder.

signals.name: RTD
signals.description: Encrypted everywhere except the South pole, Arctic Ocean, and over mainland US. Contains two OLS channels as well as the SSMIS sounder.

name: DSCOVR
description: Satellite stopped transmitting, is presumed to have failed.

signals.name: High rate link
signals.description: Transmission stopped due to a "serious software glitch" on 15-07-2025. Used to transmit SEM data as well as EPIC instrument imagery

signals.name: Low rate link
signals.description: Telemetry and some science data.

name: EWS-G1 (GOES-13)
description: GOES-13 management was transferred from NOAA to USSF in 02-2020 and became operational as EWS-G1 at 08-09-2020 providing imagery at 61.5°E for Indian Ocean monitoring. It was replaced by EWS-G2 following an imager failure at 31-10-2023. It is currently drifting in a graveyard orbit, still transmits CDA telemetry.

signals.name: GVAR
signals.description: 800 m/px VIS + 4x 4 km/px IR crop of the indian ocean every 15 minutes. Full disk transmitted at 02:45Z and every 3 hours onwards.

signals.name: CDA telemetry
signals.description: Satellite telemetry, still transmitted.

signals.name: IMAGER SD
signals.description: Raw IMAGER instrument downlink. Functionally identical to GVAR as of right now.

signals.name: Sounder SD
signals.description: Transmitted on the same frequency as IMAGER SD, contains the raw SOUNDER instrument data. Given that the SOUNDER instrument is currently disabled, this downlink is empty.

signals.name: LRIT
signals.description: Unused downlink. Transmitter noise floor is visible.

signals.name: MDL
signals.description: Unused downlink.

signals.name: S-band telemetry
signals.description: Telemetry carrier.

name: EWS-G2 (GOES-15)
description: After the failure of EWS-G1, GOES-15 management was transferred from NOAA to USSF on 22-09-2023 and the satellite was subsequently moved over to 61.5°E for Indian Ocean monitoring

signals.name: GVAR
signals.description: 800 m/px VIS + 4x 4 km/px IR crop of the indian ocean every 15 minutes. Full disk transmitted at 02:45Z and every 3 hours onwards.

signals.name: CDA telemetry
signals.description: Satellite telemetry. Currently not supported because the syncword is unknown.

signals.name: IMAGER SD
signals.description: Raw IMAGER instrument downlink. Functionally identical to GVAR as of right now.

signals.name: Sounder SD
signals.description: Transmitted on the same frequency as IMAGER SD, contains the raw SOUNDER instrument data. Given that the SOUNDER instrument is currently disabled, this downlink is empty.

signals.name: LRIT
signals.description: Unused downlink. Transmitter noise floor is visible.

signals.name: MDL
signals.description: Unused downlink.

signals.name: S-band telemetry
signals.description: Telemetry carrier.

name: Elektro-L N°2
description: Currently positioned at the 14.5°W slot. MSU-GS has several inoperational channels, the satellite has suffered a power supply failure making it unable to transmit xRIT. It has developed a high inclination due to the lack of propellant. Undergoes periodic yaw flips which significantly alter signal strength.

signals.name: LRIT
signals.description: Transmitted every 00:42 UTC and every 3 hours onwards. 06:42 and 18:42 UTC are seasonal timeslots not persent during winter months. Contains 3x VIS channels, 1x Water vapour (degraded), 1x Long-wave infrared.

signals.name: HRIT
signals.description: Transmitted every 00:12 UTC and every 3 hours onwards. 06:12 and 18:12 UTC are seasonal timeslots not persent during winter months. Contains all MSU-GS channels.

signals.name: GGAK
signals.description: Contains telemetry and SEM data. Data decoding currently unsupported due to lack of documentation.

signals.name: DCP
signals.description: Contains DCP data, currently unsupported due to unknown modulation.

signals.name: RDAS
signals.description: Raw MSU-GS data downlink. New image every 30 minutes due to power supply issues. Beamed to Moscow.

signals.name: Telemetry
signals.description: Satellite telemetry

name: Elektro-L N°3
description: Currently positioned at the 76°E slot. MSU-GS has a degraded channel 4, broken channel 10.

signals.name: LRIT
signals.description: Transmitted every 00:42 UTC and every 3 hours onwards. 06:42 and 18:42 UTC are seasonal timeslots not persent during winter months. Contains 3x VIS channels, 1x Water vapour (degraded), 1x Long-wave infrared.

signals.name: HRIT
signals.description: Transmitted every 00:12 UTC and every 3 hours onwards. 06:12 and 18:12 UTC are seasonal timeslots not persent during winter months. Contains all MSU-GS channels.

signals.name: GGAK
signals.description: Contains telemetry and SEM data. Data decoding currently unsupported due to lack of documentation.

signals.name: DCP
signals.description: Contains DCP data, currently unsupported due to unknown modulation.

signals.name: RDAS
signals.description: Raw MSU-GS data downlink. New image every 15 minutes. Beamed to Moscow.

signals.name: Telemetry
signals.description: Satellite telemetry

signals.name: LRIT
signals.description: Transmitted every 00:42 UTC and every 3 hours onwards. 06:42 and 18:42 UTC are seasonal timeslots not persent during winter months. Channels are broadcasted seemingly at random, broadcasts are often skipped. Transmission abruptly shuts down after 15 minutes.

signals.name: HRIT
signals.description: Transmitted every 00:12 UTC and every 3 hours onwards. 06:12 and 18:12 UTC are seasonal timeslots not persent during winter months. Contains all MSU-GS channels.

signals.name: GGAK
signals.description: Contains telemetry and SEM data. Data decoding currently unsupported due to lack of documentation.

signals.name: DCP
signals.description: Contains DCP data, currently unsupported due to unknown modulation.

signals.name: RDAS
signals.description: Raw MSU-GS data downlink. New image every 15 minutes. Beamed to Vladivostok.

signals.name: Telemetry
signals.description: Satellite telemetry

name: FengYun 2G
description: Spin-stabilized geostationary satellite. Has a high inclination due to low propellant, is positioned at 99.5°E

signals.name: S-VISSR
signals.description: 1.25 km/px VIS channel and 4x 5 km/px channels, transmitted every hour at XX:00. Second timeslot is at XX:30, is transmitted 01:30Z and every 4 hours after.

signals.name: LRIT
signals.description: Unused downlink.

signals.name: CDAS raw data
signals.description: Raw S-VISSR sensor downlink, transmitted right next to the 1687.5 MHz downlink. Line is transmitted in real time, groundstation processes it and *stretches* it (The S in S-VISSR), then uplinks it to the satellite so it can be downlinked at a lower symbol rate over the 1687.5 MHz transmission. Not supported due to the lack of sample data

signals.name: Telemetry
signals.description: Always active telemetry downlink.

name: FengYun 2H
description: Last spin-stabilized geostationary FengYun-2 satellite. Positioned at 79°E

signals.name: S-VISSR
signals.description: 1.25 km/px VIS channel and 4x 5 km/px channels, transmitted every hour at XX:00. Second timeslot at XX:30 transmits every hour, but only finishes the full disk at 05:30Z and every 6 hours onwards. Otherwise, LRIT is transmitted instead and the full disk gets cut off at XX:48Z.

signals.name: LRIT
signals.description: Transmitted every hour at XX:48 except 05:48Z and every 6 hours onwards. Does not transmit any imagery, is only filler throughout.

signals.name: CDAS raw data
signals.description: Raw S-VISSR sensor downlink, transmitted right next to the 1687.5 MHz downlink. Line is transmitted in real time, groundstation processes it and *stretches* it (The S in S-VISSR), then uplinks it to the satellite so it can be downlinked at a lower symbol rate over the 1687.5 MHz transmission. Not supported due to the lack of sample data

signals.name: Telemetry
signals.description: Always active telemetry downlink.

signals.description: Very strong, 1x 4 km/px IR as well as miscallenous data every 10 minutes

signals.name: HRIT
signals.description: 1x 1 km/px VIS, 4x 4 km/px IR every 10 minutes. You can see it switching from filler to data on the FFT.

signals.name: UHRIT
signals.description: Contains all AMI channels at a full resolution - as high as 0.5 km/px with VI006

signals.name: Raw data
signals.description: Possibly beamed, raw sensor downlink.

signals.name: CDAS
signals.description: It is suspected this downlink is from COMS-1, but we have no way to confirm as it has never transimtted any data. It used to be the raw downlink from the COMS-1 satellite, GK2A is known to feature compatibility with the COMS downlinks namely in its xRIT platforms.

signals.name: GVAR
signals.description: 800 m/px VIS + 4x 4 km/px IR crop of the indian ocean every 15 minutes. Full disk transmitted at 02:45Z and every 3 hours onwards.

signals.name: CDA telemetry
signals.description: Satellite telemetry, still transmitted.

signals.name: MDL
signals.description: Unused downlink.

signals.name: HRIT
signals.description: GOES 16 FD: 1x VIS + 6x IR at 2 km/px every 30 minutes, 1x VIS + 2x IR mesoscale every 15 minutes, other operational GOES 1x IR at 4 km/px every hour, Himawari 1x VIS + 2x IR at 4 km/px every hour, Meteosat: 1x IR at 15 km/px every hour, Miscallenous EMWIN

signals.name: GRB
signals.description: Half the data is transmitted over RHCP, half over LHCP. LHCP contains ABI channels 2,7,8,10,14,15,16 while RHCP contains ABI chanels 1,3,4,5,6,9,11,12,13, GOES lightning mapper, SUVI imagery, SEM data. All channels transmitted in the LHCP broadcast (besides 10 and 16) are transmitted in HRIT as well, making RHCP much more interesting to receive

signals.name: CDA telemetry
signals.description: Telemetry broadcast, can be used to verify setup functionality

signals.name: Raw downlink
signals.description: Beamed to Wallops

signals.name: HRIT
signals.description: GOES 17 FD: 1x VIS + 6x IR at 2 km/px every 30 minutes, 1x VIS + 2x IR mesoscale every 15 minutes, other operational GOES 1x IR at 4 km/px every hour, Himawari 1x VIS + 2x IR at 4 km/px every hour, Meteosat: 1x IR at 15 km/px every hour, Miscallenous EMWIN

name: Meteor-M N°2-2
description: LRPT was only active for a few months after launch due to a micrometeorite strike in 12-2019. This caused a leak of thermal transfer gas rendering LRPT inoperable. Satellite was moved to storage mode on 07-2024 due to orbital proximity to Meteor-M N°2-4.

signals.name: LRPT
signals.description: 3 JPEG-compressed 1 km/px channels. 3x VIS during summer, 2x VIS + 1x IR during winter. Rendered inoperable due to micrometeorite strike.

signals.name: HRPT
signals.description: Full resolution 6x MSU-MR channels at 1 km/px, MTVZA

signals.name: Telemetry
signals.description: Telemetry broadcast, might be seen locking onto a groundstation (drifting). Currently not supported.

signals.name: MTVZA dump
signals.description: MTVZA data from several orbits. Non-beamed dumps to Moscow, Novosibirsk, Khabrovsk. Narrow BPSK.

signals.name: IKFS dump
signals.description: Dumps from the IKFS instrument, not received yet - unconfirmed. Non-beamed dumps to Khabrovsk. Narrow QPSK.

signals.name: KMSS DB
signals.description: Direct broadcast from the KMSS instrument, active over Russia, Europe, possibly the Carribean and Brazil as well (unconfirmed). Wide BPSK.

signals.name: Main Dump
signals.description: KMSS/MSU-MR/Severjanin-M + MeteoSAR instrument data, only KMSS supported as of right now. Non-beamed dumps to Moscow, Novosibirsk, Khabrovsk. Wide QPSK.

name: Meteor-M N°2-3
description: VHF antenna didn't deploy properly due to extended storage. Wide X-band transmitter isn't used. LRPT JPEG compressor has minor issues from time to time causing pixelated imagery, the satellite has a watchdog that restarts it after a few orbits.

signals.name: LRPT
signals.description: 3 JPEG-compressed 1 km/px channels. 3x VIS during summer, 2x VIS + 1x IR during winter

signals.name: HRPT
signals.description: Full resolution 6x MSU-MR channels at 1 km/px, MTVZA

signals.name: Telemetry
signals.description: Telemetry broadcast, might be seen locking onto a groundstation (drifting). Currently not supported.

signals.name: MTVZA dump
signals.description: MTVZA data from several orbits. Non-beamed dumps to Moscow, Novosibirsk, Khabrovsk. Narrow BPSK.

signals.name: IKFS dump
signals.description: Dumps from the IKFS instrument, not received yet - unconfirmed. Non-beamed dumps to Khabrovsk. Narrow QPSK.

signals.name: KMSS DB
signals.description: Direct broadcast from the KMSS instrument, active over Russia, Europe, possibly the Carribean and Brazil as well (unconfirmed). Wide BPSK.

signals.name: Main Dump
signals.description: KMSS/MSU-MR/Severjanin-M + MeteoSAR instrument data, only KMSS supported as of right now. Non-beamed dumps to Moscow, Novosibirsk, Khabrovsk. Wide QPSK.

name: Meteor-M N°2-4
description: First fully operational Meteor-M satellite. LRPT JPEG compressor has minor issues from time to time causing pixelated imagery, the satellite has a watchdog that restarts it after a few orbits.

signals.name: LRPT
signals.description: 3 JPEG-compressed 1 km/px channels. 3x VIS during summer, 2x VIS + 1x IR during winter. 72k mode used normally, 80k only just after launch for testing.

signals.name: HRPT
signals.description: Full resolution 6x MSU-MR channels at 1 km/px, MTVZA

signals.name: Telemetry
signals.description: Telemetry broadcast, might be seen locking onto a groundstation (drifting). Currently not supported.

signals.name: MTVZA dump
signals.description: MTVZA data from several orbits. Non-beamed dumps to Moscow, Novosibirsk, Khabrovsk. Narrow BPSK.

signals.name: IKFS dump
signals.description: Dumps from the IKFS instrument, not received yet - unconfirmed. Non-beamed dumps to Khabrovsk. Narrow QPSK.

signals.name: KMSS DB
signals.description: Direct broadcast from the KMSS instrument, active over Russia, Europe, possibly the Carribean and Brazil as well (unconfirmed). Wide BPSK.

signals.name: Main Dump
signals.description: KMSS/MSU-MR/Severjanin-M + MeteoSAR instrument data, only KMSS supported as of right now. Non-beamed dumps to Moscow, Novosibirsk, Khabrovsk. Wide QPSK.

signals.name: PGS Raw data
signals.description: Contains all raw SEVIRI channels - 1x panchromatic at 1.6 km/px, 3x VIS and 9x IR all at 4.8 km/px. New image every 15 minutes in standard FD scanning mode, every 5 minutes in RSS mode.

signals.name: xRIT
signals.description: Not used in favour of the EumetCast service.

signals.name: DCP
signals.description: DCP data. Not supported due to lack of documentation.

signals.name: Telemetry
signals.description: Telemetry.

signals.name: PGS Raw data
signals.description: Contains all raw SEVIRI channels - 1x panchromatic at 1.6 km/px, 3x VIS and 9x IR all at 4.8 km/px. New image every 15 minutes in standard FD scanning mode, every 5 minutes in RSS mode.

signals.name: xRIT
signals.description: Not used in favour of the EumetCast service.

signals.name: DCP
signals.description: DCP data. Not supported due to lack of documentation.

signals.name: Telemetry
signals.description: Telemetry.

name: Meteosat-9 (MSG-2)
description: Currently positioned at 45.5°E. High inclination due to low propellant.

signals.name: PGS Raw data
signals.description: Contains all raw SEVIRI channels - 1x panchromatic at 1.6 km/px, 3x VIS and 9x IR all at 4.8 km/px. New image every 15 minutes in standard FD scanning mode, every 5 minutes in RSS mode. Meteosat-9 operates in RSS mode (?)

signals.name: xRIT
signals.description: Not used in favour of the EumetCast service.

name: NOAA 15
description: This was the longest living NOAA POES satellite until being shut down due to political reasons. Decommissioning took two tries, as the satellite rebooted a few orbits after its first one. It only used a damaged emergency antenna for L-band due to the others interfering with the AMSU instrument, this made the transmission strength very weak. AVHRR came close to stalling on several occasions, but always recovered.

signals.name: APT
signals.description: 2x 4 km/px images, during day 1x IR + 1x VIS and 2x IR during night. FFT pic is from NOAA 19

signals.name: DSB
signals.description: SEM, HIRS, Telemetry data.

signals.description: Live full resolution operational imagery from all instruments

name: Stereo-A
description: Stereo-A (Ahead) is currently in a heliocentric orbit around the sun with its sister satellite, Stereo-B (Behind), performs imaging of the Corona as well as SEM monitoring. Launched with its sister satellite, Stereo-B (Behind)

name: Stereo-B
description: Stereo-B (Behind) is in a heliocentric orbit around the sun with its sister satellite, Stereo-A (Ahead). It was used for sun imaging and SEM. A planned test of the spacecraft's automation just before the satellite passed behind the sun failed on 01-10-2014, causing the satellite to spin too quickly for the reaction wheels to correct it, resulting in a loss of communication with the spacecraft. After 22 months, on 21-08-2016, communications were restored and recovery attempts were performed through to September. On 23-09-2016, the carrier wave stopped being detected. It is suspected a frozen thruster valve came loose, increasing the spin rate even more. All subsequent attempts to find the satellite have failed.
